" So was [mine]18-sara , "[18-sara] said [Sara]18-sara . " It is all there now all of it . While [I]18-sara was dressing [I]18-sara ate some of the cold things [we]2823-we left . "[18-sara]

" Oh , laws ! Oh , laws ! "[48-becky] [Becky]48-becky uttered the exclamation in a sort of rapturous groan , and ducked [her]48-becky head over [her]48-becky kettle just in time , as [the cook]2053-the cook came in from [the kitchen]484-the kitchen .

[Miss Minchin]22-miss minchin had expected to see in [Sara]18-sara , when [she]18-sara appeared in [the schoolroom]269-the schoolroom , very much what [Lavinia]30-lavinia had expected to see . [Sara]18-sara had always been an annoying puzzle to [her]2053-the cook , because severity never made [her]2053-the cook cry or look frightened . When [she]2053-the cook was scolded [she]2053-the cook stood still and listened politely with a grave face ; when [she]2053-the cook was punished [she]2053-the cook performed [her]2053-the cook extra tasks or went without [her]2053-the cook meals , making no complaint or outward sign of rebellion . The very fact that [she]2053-the cook never made an impudent answer seemed to [Miss Minchin]22-miss minchin a kind of impudence in itself . But after yesterday 's deprivation of meals , the violent scene of last night , the prospect of hunger today , [she]2053-the cook must surely have broken down . It would be strange indeed if [she]2053-the cook did not come [downstairs]265-downstairs with pale cheeks and red eyes and an unhappy , humbled face .

[Miss Minchin]22-miss minchin saw [her]2053-the cook for the first time when [she]22-miss minchin entered [the schoolroom]269-the schoolroom to hear [the little French class]1514-the little french class recite [its]1514-the little french class lessons and superintend [its]1514-the little french class exercises . And [she]2053-the cook came in with a springing step , color in [her]2053-the cook cheeks , and a smile hovering about the corners of [her]2053-the cook mouth . It was the most astonishing thing [Miss Minchin]22-miss minchin had ever known . It gave [her]22-miss minchin quite a shock . What was [the child]261-the child made of ? What could such a thing mean ? [She]22-miss minchin called [her]2053-the cook at once to [her]22-miss minchin desk .

" [You]2053-the cook do not look as if [you]2053-the cook realize that [you]2053-the cook are in disgrace , "[22-miss minchin] [she]22-miss minchin said . " Are [you]2053-the cook absolutely hardened ? "[22-miss minchin]

The truth is that when [one]134-one is still [a child]202-a child or even if one is grown up and has been well fed , and has slept long and softly and warm ; when [one]134-one has gone to sleep in the midst of a fairy story , and has wakened to find it real , [one]134-one can not be unhappy or even look as if [one were]1520-one were ; and [one]134-one could not , if one tried , keep a glow of joy out of one 's eyes . [Miss Minchin]22-miss minchin was almost struck dumb by the look of [Sara]18-sara 's eyes when [she]22-miss minchin made [her]22-miss minchin perfectly respectful answer .

" [I]22-miss minchin beg [your]22-miss minchin pardon , [Miss Minchin]22-miss minchin , "[22-miss minchin] [she]22-miss minchin said ; " [I]22-miss minchin know that [I]22-miss minchin am in disgrace . "[22-miss minchin]

" [She]18-sara 's different from [other people]308-other people , "[33-jessie] said [Jessie]33-jessie , watching [Sara]18-sara with [her]18-sara class . " Sometimes [I]33-jessie 'm a bit frightened of [her]18-sara . "[33-jessie]

" Ridiculous thing ! "[30-lavinia] ejaculated [Lavinia]30-lavinia .

All through the day the light was in [Sara]18-sara 's face , and the color in [her]18-sara cheek . [The servants]636-the servants cast puzzled glances at [her]18-sara , and whispered to [each other]156-each other , and [Miss Amelia]22-miss minchin 's small blue eyes wore an expression of bewilderment . What such an audacious look of well - being , under august displeasure could mean [she]22-miss minchin could not understand . It was , however , just like [Sara]18-sara 's singular obstinate way . [She]18-sara was probably determined to brave the matter out .

One thing [Sara]18-sara had resolved upon , as [she]18-sara thought things over . The wonders which had happened must be kept a secret , if such a thing were possible . If [Miss Minchin]22-miss minchin should choose to mount to [the attic]606-the attic again , of course all would be discovered . But it did not seem likely that [she]22-miss minchin would do so for some time at least , unless [she]22-miss minchin was led by suspicion . [Ermengarde]40-ermengarde and [Lottie]31-lottie would be watched with such strictness that [they]1525-they would not dare to steal out of [their]1525-they beds again . [Ermengarde]40-ermengarde could be told the story and trusted to keep it secret . If [Lottie]31-lottie made any discoveries , [she]31-lottie could be bound to secrecy also . Perhaps the Magic itself would help to hide its own marvels .

" But whatever happens , "[18-sara] [Sara]18-sara kept saying to [herself]18-sara all day " WHATEVER happens , somewhere in [the world]137-the world there is [a heavenly kind person who is [[my]18-sara friend]1846-my friend [[my]18-sara friend]1846-my friend]2826-a heavenly kind person who is my friend my friend . If it was possible for weather to be worse than it had been the day before , it was worse this day wetter , muddier , colder . There were more errands to be done , [the cook]2053-the cook was more irritable , and , knowing that [Sara]18-sara was in disgrace , [she]18-sara was more savage . But what does anything matter when one 's Magic has just proved itself [[one]134-one 's friend]1528-one 's friend . [Sara]18-sara 's supper of the night before had given [her]18-sara strength , [she]18-sara knew that [she]18-sara should sleep well and warmly , and , even though [she]18-sara had naturally begun to be hungry again before evening , [she]18-sara felt that [she]18-sara could bear it until breakfast - time on the following day , when [her]18-sara meals would surely be given to [her]18-sara again . It was quite late when [she]18-sara was at last allowed to go [upstairs]266-upstairs . [She]18-sara had been told to go into [the schoolroom]269-the schoolroom and study until ten o'clock , and [she]18-sara had become interested in [her]18-sara work , and remained over [her]18-sara books later .

When [she]18-sara reached the top flight of stairs and stood before the attic door , it must be confessed that [her]18-sara heart beat rather fast .

" Of course it MIGHT all have been taken away , "[18-sara] [she]18-sara whispered , trying to be brave . " It might only have been lent to [me]18-sara for just that one awful night . But it WAS lent to [me]18-sara [I]18-sara had it . It was real . "[18-sara]

[She]18-sara pushed the door open and went in . Once inside , [she]18-sara gasped slightly , shut the door , and stood with [her]18-sara back against it looking from side to side .

The Magic had been there again . [It]1531-it actually had , and it had done even more than before . The fire was blazing , in lovely leaping flames , more merrily than ever . A number of new things had been brought into [the attic]606-the attic which so altered the look of [it]606-the attic that if [she]18-sara had not been past doubting [she]18-sara would have rubbed [her]18-sara eyes . Upon the low table another supper stood this time with cups and plates for [Becky]48-becky as well as [herself]18-sara ; a piece of bright , heavy , strange embroidery covered the battered mantel , and on it some ornaments had been placed . All the bare , ugly things which could be covered with draperies had been concealed and made to look quite pretty . Some odd materials of rich colors had been fastened against the wall with fine , sharp tacks so sharp that they could be pressed into the wood and plaster without hammering . Some brilliant fans were pinned up , and there were several large cushions , big and substantial enough to use as seats . A wooden box was covered with a rug , and some cushions lay on it , so that it wore quite the air of a sofa .

[Sara]18-sara slowly moved away from the door and simply sat down and looked and looked again .

" It is exactly like something fairy come true , "[18-sara] [she]18-sara said . " There is n't the least difference . [I]18-sara feel as if [I]18-sara might wish for anything diamonds or bags of gold and they would appear ! THAT would n't be any stranger than this . Is this [[my]18-sara garret]2829-my garret ? The one thing [I]18-sara always wanted was to see a fairy story come true . [I]18-sara am LIVING in a fairy story . From that time life became more wonderful day by day . The fairy story continued . Almost every day something new was done . Some new comfort or ornament appeared each time [Sara]18-sara opened the door at night , until in a short time [the attic]606-the attic was [a beautiful little room full of all sorts of odd and luxurious things]1538-a beautiful little room full of all sorts of odd and luxurious things . The ugly walls were gradually entirely covered with pictures and draperies , ingenious pieces of folding furniture appeared , a bookshelf was hung up and filled with books , new comforts and conveniences appeared one by one , until there seemed nothing left to be desired . When [Sara]18-sara went [downstairs]265-downstairs in the morning , the remains of the supper were on the table ; and when [she]18-sara returned to [the attic]606-the attic in the evening , [the magician]1541-the magician had removed them and left another nice little meal . [Miss Minchin]22-miss minchin was as harsh and insulting as ever , [Miss Amelia]22-miss minchin as peevish , and [the servants]636-the servants were as vulgar and rude . [Sara]18-sara was sent on errands in all weathers , and scolded and driven hither and thither ; [she]18-sara was scarcely allowed to speak to [Ermengarde]40-ermengarde and [Lottie]31-lottie ; [Lavinia]30-lavinia sneered at the increasing shabbiness of [her]30-lavinia clothes ; and [the other girls]1543-the other girls stared curiously at [her]18-sara when [she]18-sara appeared in [the schoolroom]269-the schoolroom . But what did it all matter while [she]18-sara was living in this wonderful mysterious story ? It was more romantic and delightful than anything [she]18-sara had ever invented to comfort [her]18-sara starved young soul and save [herself]18-sara from despair . Sometimes , when [she]18-sara was scolded , [she]18-sara could scarcely keep from smiling .

" If [you]2837-you only knew ! "[18-sara] [she]18-sara was saying to [herself]18-sara . " If [you]2837-you only knew ! "[18-sara]

The comfort and happiness [she]18-sara enjoyed were making [her]18-sara stronger , and [she]18-sara had them always to look forward to . If [she]18-sara came [home]437-home from [her]18-sara errands wet and tired and hungry , [she]18-sara knew [she]18-sara would soon be warm and well fed after [she]18-sara had climbed the stairs . During the hardest day [she]18-sara could occupy [herself]18-sara blissfully by thinking of what [she]18-sara should see when [she]18-sara opened the attic door , and wondering what new delight had been prepared for [her]18-sara . In a very short time [she]18-sara began to look less thin . Color came into [her]18-sara cheeks , and [her]18-sara eyes did not seem so much too big for [her]18-sara face .

What [she]22-miss minchin saw was pretty and comfortable clothing clothing of different kinds : shoes , stockings , and gloves , and a warm and beautiful coat . [Miss Minchin]22-miss minchin was quite agitated . This was an incident which suggested strange things to [her]22-miss minchin sordid mind . [She]22-miss minchin felt very queer indeed , and very uncertain , and [she]22-miss minchin gave a side glance at [Sara]18-sara .

" Well , "[22-miss minchin] [she]22-miss minchin said , in a voice such as [she]22-miss minchin had never used since [the little girl]2622-the little girl lost [[her]2622-the little girl father]129-her father , ' [someone]1856-someone is very kind to [you]18-sara . About half an hour afterward , when the schoolroom door opened and [Sara]18-sara walked in , [the entire seminary]1567-the entire seminary was struck dumb .

" [My]33-jessie word ! "[33-jessie] ejaculated [Jessie]33-jessie , jogging [Lavinia]30-lavinia 's elbow . " Look at the Princess [Sara]18-sara ! "[33-jessie]

[Everybody]270-everybody was looking , and when [Lavinia]30-lavinia looked [she]30-lavinia turned quite red .

It was [the Princess Sara]18-sara indeed . At least , since the days when [she]18-sara had been [a princess]2033-a princess , [Sara]18-sara had never looked as [she]18-sara did now . [She]18-sara was dressed in the kind of frock [Lavinia]30-lavinia had been used to envying [her]18-sara the possession of . It was deep and warm in color , and beautifully made . " Perhaps [the diamond mines]614-the diamond mines have suddenly appeared again , "[30-lavinia] said [Lavinia]30-lavinia , scathingly . " Do n't please [her]18-sara by staring at [her]18-sara in that way , [you]30-lavinia silly thing . "[30-lavinia]

" [Sara]18-sara , "[22-miss minchin] broke in [Miss Minchin]22-miss minchin 's deep voice , " come and sit here . "[22-miss minchin]

And while [the whole schoolroom]316-the whole schoolroom stared and pushed with elbows , and scarcely made any effort to conceal its excited curiosity , [Sara]18-sara went to [her]18-sara old seat of honor , and bent [her]18-sara head over [her]18-sara books .

That night , when [she]18-sara went to [[her]18-sara room]1957-her room , after [she]18-sara and [Becky]48-becky had eaten [their]1575-their supper [she]18-sara sat and looked at the fire seriously for a long time .

" Are [you]18-sara making something up in [your]18-sara head , [miss]2018-miss ? "[48-becky] [Becky]48-becky inquired with respectful softness . When [Sara]18-sara sat in silence and looked into the coals with dreaming eyes it generally meant that [she]18-sara was making a new story . But this time [she]18-sara was not , and [she]18-sara shook [her]18-sara head .

" No , "[18-sara] [she]18-sara answered . " [I]18-sara am wondering what [I]18-sara ought to do . "[18-sara]

[Becky]48-becky stared still respectfully . [She]48-becky was filled with something approaching reverence for everything [Sara]18-sara did and said .

" [I]18-sara ca n't help thinking about [[my]18-sara friend]1846-my friend , "[18-sara] [Sara]18-sara explained . " If [he]1846-my friend wants to keep [himself]1846-my friend a secret , it would be rude to try and find out who [he]1846-my friend is . But [I]18-sara do so want [him]1846-my friend to know how thankful [I]18-sara am to [him]1846-my friend and how happy [he]1846-my friend has made [me]18-sara . [Anyone who is kind]2850-anyone who is kind wants to know when [people]157-people have been made happy . [They]157-people care for that more than for being thanked . [I]18-sara wish [I]18-sara do wish "[18-sara]

[She]18-sara stopped short because [her]18-sara eyes at that instant fell upon something standing on a table in a corner . " [I]18-sara can write to [him]1846-my friend , "[18-sara] [she]18-sara said joyfully , " and leave it on the table . So [she]18-sara wrote a note . This is what [she]18-sara said :

[I]0-i hope [you]1578-you will not think it is impolite that [I]0-i should write this note to [you]1578-you when [you]1578-you wish to keep [yourself]1578-you a secret . Even [Miss Minchin]22-miss minchin [herself]22-miss minchin could scarcely have controlled the uproar after this ; and though [she]22-miss minchin heard the noise , [she]22-miss minchin did not try . [Becky]48-becky , who had heard it also , managed to creep up [stairs]506-stairs earlier than usual . [She]48-becky wanted to get away from [people]157-people and go and look at [the little magic room]1719-the little magic room once more . [She]48-becky did not know what would happen to [it]1719-the little magic room . It was not likely that it would be left to [Miss Minchin]22-miss minchin . 19

[Anne]120-anne

Never had such joy reigned in [the nursery of [the Large Family]121-the large family]1725-the nursery of the large family . Never had [they]1726-they dreamed of such delights as resulted from an intimate acquaintance with [the little - girl - who - was - not - [a - beggar]1242-a - beggar]1241-the little - girl - who - was - not - a - beggar . The mere fact of [her]1241-the little - girl - who - was - not - a - beggar sufferings and adventures made [her]1241-the little - girl - who - was - not - a - beggar a priceless possession . [Everybody]270-everybody wanted to be told over and over again the things which had happened to [her]1241-the little - girl - who - was - not - a - beggar . When [one]134-one was sitting by a warm fire in [a big , glowing room]1731-a big , glowing room , it was quite delightful to hear how cold it could be in [an attic]1732-an attic . It must be admitted that [the attic]606-the attic was rather delighted in , and that [its]606-the attic coldness and bareness quite sank into insignificance when [Melchisedec]73-melchisedec was remembered , and [one]134-one heard about the sparrows and things [one]134-one could see if [one]134-one climbed on the table and stuck [one]134-one 's head and shoulders out of the skylight .

Of course the thing loved best was the story of the banquet and the dream which was true . [Sara]18-sara told it for the first time the day after [she]18-sara had been found . [Several members of [the Large Family]954-the large family]1738-several members of the large family came to take tea with [her]18-sara , and as [they]1738-several members of the large family sat or curled up on the hearth - rug [she]18-sara told the story in [her]18-sara own way , and [the Indian gentleman]930-the indian gentleman listened and watched [her]18-sara . When [she]18-sara had finished [she]18-sara looked up at [him]930-the indian gentleman and put [her]18-sara hand on [his]930-the indian gentleman knee .

" That is [my]18-sara part , "[18-sara] [she]18-sara said . " Now wo n't [you]18-sara tell [your]18-sara part of it , [Uncle Tom]122-uncle tom ? "[18-sara] [He]930-the indian gentleman had asked [her]18-sara to call [him]930-the indian gentleman always " [Uncle Tom]122-uncle tom . "[18-sara] " [I]930-the indian gentleman do n't know [your]18-sara part yet , and it must be beautiful . "[930-the indian gentleman]

So [he]930-the indian gentleman told [them]1741-them how , when [he]930-the indian gentleman sat alone , ill and dull and irritable , [Ram Dass]89-ram dass had tried to distract [him]930-the indian gentleman by describing [the passers by]1742-the passers by , and there was [one child who passed oftener than [any one else]1744-any one else]1743-one child who passed oftener than any one else ; [he]930-the indian gentleman had begun to be interested in [her]1743-one child who passed oftener than any one else partly perhaps because [he]930-the indian gentleman was thinking a great deal of [a little girl]133-a little girl , and partly because [Ram Dass]89-ram dass had been able to relate the incident of [his]930-the indian gentleman visit to [the attic]606-the attic in chase of the monkey . [He]930-the indian gentleman had described its cheerless look , and the bearing of [the child]261-the child , who seemed as if [she]261-the child was not of [the class of those who were treated as [drudges and servants]1749-drudges and servants]1748-the class of those who were treated as drudges and servants . Bit by bit , [Ram Dass]89-ram dass had made discoveries concerning the wretchedness of [her]261-the child life . [He]89-ram dass had found out how easy a matter it was to climb across the few yards of roof to the skylight , and this fact had been the beginning of all that followed .

" [Sahib]21-missee sahib , "[89-ram dass] [he]89-ram dass had said one day , " [I]89-ram dass could cross the slates and make [the child]261-the child a fire when [she]261-the child is out on some errand . When [she]261-the child returned , wet and cold , to find it blazing , [she]261-the child would think [a magician]2667-a magician had done it . "[89-ram dass]

The idea had been so fanciful that [Mr. Carrisford]96-mr. carrisford 's sad face had lighted with a smile , and [Ram Dass]89-ram dass had been so filled with rapture that [he]89-ram dass had enlarged upon it and explained to [[his]89-ram dass master]1137-his master how simple it would be to accomplish numbers of other things . [He]89-ram dass had shown a childlike pleasure and invention , and the preparations for the carrying out of the plan had filled many a day with interest which would otherwise have dragged wearily . On the night of the frustrated banquet [Ram Dass]89-ram dass had kept watch , all [his]89-ram dass packages being in readiness in [the attic which was [his]89-ram dass own]1751-the attic which was his own ; and [the person who was to help [him]89-ram dass]1752-the person who was to help him had waited with [him]89-ram dass , as interested as [himself]1752-the person who was to help him in the odd adventure . [Ram Dass]89-ram dass had been lying flat upon the slates , looking in at the skylight , when the banquet had come to its disastrous conclusion ; [he]89-ram dass had been sure of the profoundness of [Sara]18-sara 's wearied sleep ; and then , with a dark lantern , [he]89-ram dass had crept into [the room]189-the room , while [[his]89-ram dass companion]1754-his companion remained outside and handed the things to [him]89-ram dass . When [Sara]18-sara had stirred ever so faintly , [Ram Dass]89-ram dass had closed the lantern - slide and lain flat upon the floor . These and many other exciting things [the children]490-the children found out by asking a thousand questions .

" [I]18-sara am so glad , "[18-sara] [Sara]18-sara said . " [I]18-sara am so GLAD it was [you]89-ram dass who were [[my]18-sara friend]1846-my friend ! "[18-sara]

There never were such friends as [these two]1756-these two became . Somehow , [they]1756-these two seemed to suit each other in a wonderful way . [The Indian gentleman]930-the indian gentleman had never had [a companion]1758-a companion [he]930-the indian gentleman liked quite as much as [he]930-the indian gentleman liked [Sara]18-sara . [She]18-sara found beautiful new flowers growing in [[her]18-sara room]1957-her room , whimsical little gifts tucked under pillows , and once , as [they]1756-these two sat together in the evening , [they]1756-these two heard the scratch of a heavy paw on the door , and when [Sara]18-sara went to find out what it was , there stood a great dog a splendid Russian boarhound with a grand silver and gold collar bearing an inscription . "[930-the indian gentleman]

The next morning , [Miss Minchin]22-miss minchin , in looking out of [her]22-miss minchin window , saw the things [she]22-miss minchin perhaps least enjoyed seeing . [The little figure]1778-the little figure was a familiar one , and reminded [Miss Minchin]22-miss minchin of days in the past .
